docs.lead_paragraph: The wildfire success of ''Listening to Prozac'' made Peter Kramer possibly the best-known psychiatrist in America -- and, with the headlines pigeonholing him as the ''Pied Piper of Prozac,'' possibly the most misunderstood. Dr. Kramer's 1993 book captured a revolutionary moment in psychiatry, the advent of an exciting new class of anti-depressants. But he was never painting the portrait of a panacea. He never would. For as his work since then -- a nuanced book about relationships and a novel-in-progress about an anarchist -- bears out, he, like psychotherapy itself, is neither smooth nor easy.

headline.main: Listening to Dr. Prozac; From Depression to Separation, a Therapist Resists Easy Answers

docs.abstract: Profile of Dr Peter Kramer, author of books Listening to Prozac and When Should You Leave, about troubled couples, and book-in-progress about an anarchist; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Giving a major lift to critics of affirmative action, Washington State voters tonight appear to have soundly approved an initiative that would ban most state-supported forms of the policy. They did so two years after California voters made theirs the first state in the nation to do so, and the vote is almost certain to spur efforts in other states. With 38 percent of precincts reporting, the measure known as Initiative 200 was running ahead, 60 percent to 40 percent. Under the measure's wording, the state ''shall not discriminate against, or grant preferential treatment to, any individual or group on the basis of race, sex, color, ethnicity, or national origin'' in education, employment or contracting.

headline.main: Voters Back End to State Preferences

docs.abstract: Washington State voters approve referendum that would ban most state supported forms of affirmative action; pass referendums that would legalize use of marijuana for medical purposes, vote down proposal to criminalize late-term abortion procedure; Michigan voters reject proposal to legalize doctor-assisted suicide; Massachusetts voters back campaign-finance reform referendum (M)
